segments.text: "Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the Buonapartes. But I warn you, if you don’t tell me that this means war, if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that Antichrist—I really believe he is Antichrist—I will have nothing more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my ‘faithful slave,’ as you call yourself!"
segments.instruction: Deliver this speech with a strong, concerned tone, conveying Anna Pavlovna's exasperation but maintaining a refined air.

segments.text: But how do you do? I see I have frightened you—sit down and tell me all the news.
segments.instruction: Shift to a slightly softer, more concerned tone here, showing a transition to a more welcoming demeanor.

segments.text: It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pávlovna Schérer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Márya Fëdorovna. With these words she greeted Prince Vasíli Kurágin, a man of high rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna Pávlovna had had a cough for some days. She was, as she said, suffering from la grippe; grippe being then a new word in St. Petersburg, used only by the elite.
segments.instruction: Deliver this descriptive passage with a clear, neutral tone, setting the scene and introducing the characters.

segments.text: All her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered by a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows:
segments.instruction: Maintain a neutral tone, setting the context for the following quote.

segments.text: "If you have nothing better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the prospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too terrible, I shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10—Annette Schérer."
segments.instruction: Read this invitation with a polite, refined tone, reflecting Anna Pavlovna's social standing.

segments.text: "Heavens! what a virulent attack!"
segments.instruction: Deliver this line with a light, amused tone, hinting at sarcasm.

segments.text: replied the prince, not in the least disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing an embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that refined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but thought, and with the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a man of importance who had grown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna Pávlovna, kissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, scented, and shining head, and complacently seated himself on the sofa.
segments.instruction: Describe the prince's entrance and demeanor with a clear, descriptive tone.

segments.text: "First of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend’s mind at rest,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a polite, yet subtly insincere tone, reflecting the prince's character.

segments.text: said he without altering his tone, beneath the politeness and affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony could be discerned.
segments.instruction: Maintain a neutral tone, providing commentary on the prince's words and demeanor.

segments.text: "Can one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times like these if one has any feeling?"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a thoughtful, somewhat somber tone, reflecting Anna Pavlovna's feelings.

segments.text: "You are staying the whole evening, I hope?"
segments.instruction: Convey a hopeful yet slightly anxious tone in this question.

segments.text: "And the fete at the English ambassador’s? Today is Wednesday. I must put in an appearance there,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this casually, with a slightly bored undertone.

segments.text: said the prince. "My daughter is coming for me to take me there."
segments.instruction: Maintain a casual tone here.

segments.text: "I thought today’s fete had been canceled. I confess all these festivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome."
segments.instruction: Express weariness and boredom in this line.

segments.text: "If they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have been put off,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with an insincere, polite tone.

segments.text: said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force of habit said things he did not even wish to be believed.
segments.instruction: Provide commentary on the prince's words, maintaining a neutral tone.

segments.text: "Don’t tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novosíltsev’s dispatch? You know everything."
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a slightly impatient tone.

segments.text: "What can one say about it?"
segments.instruction: Convey disinterest and apathy in this response.

segments.text: replied the prince in a cold, listless tone.
segments.instruction: Describe the prince's tone neutrally.

segments.text: "What has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours."
segments.instruction: Deliver this dialogue with a languid, somewhat bored tone, as if reciting a familiar line.

segments.text: Prince Vasíli always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a stale part.
segments.instruction: Read this description with a neutral tone, setting the scene and characterizing Prince Vasíli.

segments.text: Anna Pávlovna Schérer on the contrary, despite her forty years, overflowed with animation and impulsiveness.
segments.instruction: Maintain a neutral tone, contrasting Prince Vasíli's demeanor with Anna Pávlovna's.

segments.text: To be an enthusiast had become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not feel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the expectations of those who knew her.
segments.instruction: Continue with a neutral, descriptive tone, elaborating on Anna Pávlovna's character.

segments.text: The subdued smile which, though it did not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed, as in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charming defect, which she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to correct.
segments.instruction: Describe her smile with a slightly more observant and insightful tone.

segments.text: In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna Pávlovna burst out:
segments.instruction: Set the scene for Anna Pávlovna's outburst with a neutral and descriptive tone.

segments.text: "Oh, don’t speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don’t understand things, but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She is betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious sovereign recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is the one thing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to perform the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that God will not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of revolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of this murderer and villain! We alone must avenge the blood of the just one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... England with her commercial spirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexander’s loftiness of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to find, and still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer did Novosíltsev get? None. The English have not understood and cannot understand the self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for himself, but only desires the good of mankind. And what have they promised? Nothing! And what little they have promised they will not perform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and that all Europe is powerless before him.... And I don’t believe a word that Hardenburg says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian neutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty destiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!"
segments.instruction: Deliver this speech with strong emotion, conveying Anna Pávlovna's passionate and indignant feelings. Vary the pace and emphasis to reflect the emotional shifts within the speech.

segments.text: She suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity.
segments.instruction: Describe her sudden pause and smile with a neutral, observant tone.

segments.text: "I think," said the prince with a smile, "that if you had been sent instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the King of Prussia’s consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you give me a cup of tea?"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a light, amused tone, contrasting with Anna Pávlovna's previous intensity.

segments.text: "In a moment. À propos," she added, becoming calm again, "I am expecting two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who is connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of the best French families. He is one of the genuine émigrés, the good ones. And also the Abbé Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been received by the Emperor."
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a calmer, more composed tone, shifting back to a conversational manner.

segments.text: “Had you heard?”
segments.instruction: Deliver this question with a curious and slightly inquisitive tone.

segments.text: “I shall be delighted to meet them,”
segments.instruction: Deliver this response with a polite and somewhat formal tone.

segments.text: said the prince.
segments.instruction: Deliver this dialogue tag naturally, setting the scene.

segments.text: “But tell me,”
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a slightly more inquisitive tone than the previous line.

segments.text: he added with studied carelessness as if it had only just occurred to him, though the question he was about to ask was the chief motive of his visit,
segments.instruction: Describe this action with a subtle hint of irony.

segments.text: “is it true that the Dowager Empress wants Baron Funke to be appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all accounts is a poor creature.”
segments.instruction: Deliver this question with a hint of skepticism, reflecting the prince's underlying motive.

segments.text: Prince Vasíli wished to obtain this post for his son, but others were trying through the Dowager Empress Márya Fëdorovna to secure it for the baron.
segments.instruction: Deliver this narrative section with a clear and concise tone.

segments.text: Anna Pávlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she nor anyone else had a right to criticize what the Empress desired or was pleased with.
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pavlovna's action with a hint of subtle drama.

segments.text: “Baron Funke has been recommended to the Dowager Empress by her sister,”
segments.instruction: Deliver this statement with a reserved and somewhat formal tone.

segments.text: was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone.
segments.instruction: Describe her tone accurately.

segments.text: As she named the Empress, Anna Pávlovna’s face suddenly assumed an expression of profound and sincere devotion and respect mingled with sadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious patroness.
segments.instruction: Paint a vivid picture of Anna Pavlovna's emotional state.

segments.text: She added that Her Majesty had deigned to show Baron Funke beaucoup d’estime, and again her face clouded over with sadness.
segments.instruction: Continue describing her demeanor with precision.

segments.text: The prince was silent and looked indifferent.
segments.instruction: Deliver this observation with a neutral tone.

segments.text: But, with the womanly and courtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna Pávlovna wished both to rebuke him (for daring to speak as he had done of a man recommended to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, so she said:
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pavlovna's intentions clearly.

segments.text: “Now about your family.
segments.instruction: Deliver this line with a subtle shift in tone, transitioning to a more personal topic.

segments.text: Do you know that since your daughter came out everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazingly beautiful.”
segments.instruction: Convey genuine admiration for the prince's daughter.

segments.text: The prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude.
segments.instruction: Describe the prince's reaction concisely.

segments.text: “I often think,”
segments.instruction: Deliver this line with a thoughtful and reflective tone.

segments.text: she continued after a short pause, drawing nearer to the prince and smiling amiably at him as if to show that political and social topics were ended and the time had come for intimate conversation—“I often think how unfairly sometimes the joys of life are distributed.
segments.instruction: Describe the change in the conversation's dynamic smoothly.

segments.text: Why has fate given you two such splendid children? I don’t speak of Anatole, your youngest.
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a hint of criticism regarding Anatole.

segments.text: I don’t like him,”
segments.instruction: Convey clear disapproval of Anatole.

segments.text: she added in a tone admitting of no rejoinder and raising her eyebrows.
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pavlovna's demeanor accurately.

segments.text: “Two such charming children.
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a tone of admiration.

segments.text: And really you appreciate them less than anyone, and so you don’t deserve to have them.”
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a slightly teasing yet affectionate tone.

segments.text: And she smiled her ecstatic smile.
segments.instruction: Describe her smile vividly.

segments.text: “I can’t help it,”
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a self-deprecating tone.

segments.text: said the prince.
segments.instruction: Deliver this dialogue tag smoothly.

segments.text: “Lavater would have said I lack the bump of paternity.”
segments.instruction: Deliver this line with a touch of humor.

segments.text: “Don’t joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you.
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a serious and concerned tone.

segments.text: Do you know I am dissatisfied with your younger son?
segments.instruction: Express concern regarding the younger son.

segments.text: Between ourselves”
segments.instruction: Deliver this in a confidential tone.

segments.text: (and her face assumed its melancholy expression), “he was mentioned at Her Majesty’s and you were pitied....”
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pavlovna's expression.

segments.text: The prince answered nothing, but she looked at him significantly, awaiting a reply.
segments.instruction: Describe the interaction between the two characters.

segments.text: He frowned.
segments.instruction: Deliver this concisely.

segments.text: “What would you have me do?”
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a hint of frustration.

segments.text: he said at last.
segments.instruction: Deliver this smoothly.

segments.text: “You know I did all a father could for their education, and they have both turned out fools.
segments.instruction: Convey the prince's sadness and disappointment.

segments.text: Hippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active one.
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a tone of resignation.

segments.text: That is the only difference between them.
segments.instruction: Deliver this line with a subtle, amused tone, hinting at a hidden meaning.

segments.text: He said this smiling in a way more natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles round his mouth very clearly revealed something unexpectedly coarse and unpleasant.
segments.instruction: Describe the character's smile and its unexpected effect with a neutral tone, highlighting the contrast.

segments.text: "And why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a father there would be nothing I could reproach you with,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a thoughtful yet slightly accusing tone, reflecting Anna Pávlovna's pensive mood.

segments.text: said Anna Pávlovna, looking up pensively.
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pávlovna's action with a calm and neutral tone.

segments.text: "I am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my children are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That is how I explain it to myself. It can’t be helped!"
segments.instruction: Convey a sense of weariness and resignation in this confession, emphasizing the character's burden.

segments.text: He said no more, but expressed his resignation to cruel fate by a gesture.
segments.instruction: Describe the character's gesture and its meaning with a neutral and descriptive tone.

segments.text: Anna Pávlovna meditated.
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pávlovna's action briefly and neutrally.

segments.text: "Have you never thought of marrying your prodigal son Anatole?"
segments.instruction: Deliver this question with a suggestive and slightly inquisitive tone.

segments.text: "They say old maids have a mania for matchmaking, and though I don’t feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little person who is very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of yours, Princess Mary Bolkónskaya."
segments.instruction: Deliver this explanation with a matter-of-fact yet slightly mischievous tone.

segments.text: Prince Vasíli did not reply, though, with the quickness of memory and perception befitting a man of the world, he indicated by a movement of the head that he was considering this information.
segments.instruction: Describe Prince Vasíli's reaction with a neutral tone, emphasizing his worldly nature.

segments.text: "Do you know,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a pensive and slightly weary tone.

segments.text: he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad current of his thoughts,
segments.instruction: Describe the character's state of mind with a neutral tone.

segments.text: "that Anatole is costing me forty thousand rubles a year? And,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a tone of concern and slight exasperation.

segments.text: he went on after a pause,
segments.instruction: Describe the pause and continuation with a neutral tone.

segments.text: "what will it be in five years, if he goes on like this?"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a tone of growing concern.

segments.text: Presently he added:
segments.instruction: Use a neutral tone to indicate the passage of time.

segments.text: "That’s what we fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours rich?"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a slightly resigned tone, reflecting his weariness.

segments.text: "Her father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. He is the well-known Prince Bolkónski who had to retire from the army under the late Emperor, and was nicknamed ‘the King of Prussia.’ He is very clever but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is very unhappy. She has a brother; I think you know him, he married Lise Meinen lately. He is an aide-de-camp of Kutúzov’s and will be here tonight."
segments.instruction: Deliver this information with a sympathetic yet informative tone.

segments.text: "Listen, dear Annette,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a determined tone, indicating a shift in his focus.

segments.text: said the prince, suddenly taking Anna Pávlovna’s hand and for some reason drawing it downwards.
segments.instruction: Describe the prince's action with a neutral and descriptive tone.

segments.text: "Arrange that affair for me and I shall always be your most devoted slave-slafe with an f, as a village elder of mine writes in his reports. She is rich and of good family and that’s all I want."
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a determined yet slightly playful tone, highlighting the amusing misspelling.

segments.text: And with the familiarity and easy grace peculiar to him, he raised the maid of honor’s hand to his lips, kissed it, and swung it to and fro as he lay back in his armchair, looking in another direction.
segments.instruction: Describe the prince's actions with a neutral and descriptive tone, emphasizing his ease and grace.

segments.text: "Attendez,"
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a reflective and thoughtful tone.

segments.text: said Anna Pávlovna, reflecting,
segments.instruction: Describe Anna Pávlovna's action with a neutral tone.

segments.text: "I’ll speak to Lise, young Bolkónski’s wife, this very evening, and perhaps the thing can be arranged. It shall be on your family’s behalf that I’ll start my apprenticeship as old maid."
segments.instruction: Deliver this with a determined yet slightly amused tone, hinting at her own amusement.
